title: Announcement of Pit Closures
description: The National Coal Board informed miners at Cortonwood their pit would close in five weeks, despite earlier assurances of a longer lifespan.

title: Beginning of the Miners' Strike
description: Cortonwood miners walked out on March 5, followed by other Yorkshire pits. The Yorkshire NUM backed the walkouts and a national strike began on March 12.

title: Battle of Orgreave
description: Violent clashes between striking miners and police took place at the Orgreave coking plant in South Yorkshire, with mounted police charges and many injuries.

title: The 'Enemy Within' Speech
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher referred to militant miners' leaders and certain councils as 'the enemy within' in a speech to the 1922 Committee.

title: Brighton Hotel Bombing
description: An IRA bomb exploded at the Grand Hotel in Brighton during the Conservative Party Conference, killing five people and injuring many others.

title: Grimethorpe Slag Heap Arrests
description: Twenty-two people were arrested in Grimethorpe for collecting coal from a slag heap to heat their homes during the strike, later prompting an official apology.

title: LGSM Solidarity
description: Lesbians and Gays Support the Miners (LGSM) formed to raise funds and support for striking mining communities, building solidarity across groups.

title: End of the Miners' Strike
description: The strike ended without a deal. Miners in many areas returned to work together, including highly symbolic community marches.

title: Live Aid
description: A major dual-venue concert at Wembley Stadium (London) and JFK Stadium (Philadelphia) raised funds for the Ethiopian famine.

title: Chernobyl Disaster
description: A catastrophic nuclear accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant released radioactive contamination across Europe.

title: The 'Big Bang'
description: Deregulation of the City of London's financial markets reshaped the UK economy and the culture of the financial district.

title: 1987 General Election
description: The Conservative Party won a third consecutive term under Margaret Thatcher.

title: Signing of the INF Treaty
description: Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev signed the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty in Washington, D.C.

title: Enactment of Section 28
description: Section 28 became law as part of the Local Government Act 1988, restricting local authorities from 'promoting homosexuality' or 'pretended family relationships'.

title: Poll Tax Implementation in Scotland
description: The Community Charge (Poll Tax) was introduced in Scotland a year earlier than in England and Wales, sparking mass non-payment campaigns.

title: Hillsborough Disaster
description: A fatal human crush occurred at Hillsborough Stadium during an FA Cup semi-final, resulting in 97 deaths and widespread trauma.

title: Fall of the Berlin Wall
description: Following weeks of civil unrest, the border between East and West Berlin opened and citizens began dismantling the wall.

title: Battle of Trafalgar Square
description: A national demonstration against the Poll Tax in London culminated in a riot in Trafalgar Square, involving mounted police charges and arson.

title: Mass Poll Tax Summonses
description: Magistrates' courts were flooded with summonses for non-payment of the Poll Tax, leading to coordinated defense efforts and court-clogging tactics.

title: Resignation of Margaret Thatcher
description: After a leadership challenge, Thatcher resigned as Prime Minister and Leader of the Conservative Party.
